
### xv6 spinlock: acquire  {.smaller}


<pre><code>void
acquire(struct spinlock *lk)
{
  <span data-fragment-index="2" class="fragment custom myem-only">pushcli();</span> // disable interrupts to avoid deadlock.
  ...
  // The xchg is atomic.
  <span data-fragment-index="3" class="fragment custom myem-only">while(xchg(&amp;lk-&gt;locked, 1) != 0)</span>
    ; 

  // Tell the C compiler and the processor to not move loads or stores
  // past this point, to ensure that the critical section's memory
  // references happen after the lock is acquired.
  <span data-fragment-index="4" class="fragment custom myem-only">__sync_synchronize();</span>
  ...
}
</code></pre>

### xv6 spinlock: release  {.smaller}


<pre><code>void
release(struct spinlock *lk)
  ...
  // Tell the C compiler and the processor to not move loads or stores
  // past this point, to ensure that all the stores in the critical
  // section are visible to other cores before the lock is released.
  // Both the C compiler and the hardware may re-order loads and
  // stores; __sync_synchronize() tells them both not to.
  <span data-fragment-index="2" class="fragment custom myem-only">__sync_synchronize();</span>

  // Release the lock, equivalent to lk-&gt;locked = 0.
  // This code can't use a C assignment, since it might
  // not be atomic. A real OS would use C atomics here.
  <span data-fragment-index="3" class="fragment custom myem-only">asm volatile("movl $0, %0" : "+m" (lk-&gt;locked) : );</span>

  <span data-fragment-index="4" class="fragment custom myem-only">popcli();</span>
}
</code></pre>
